description.en: The course gives a general introduction to the role of materials in modern technologies. The main part of the course concentrates on a systematic overview of different classes of materials, their properties and applications. Problem-solving is practiced.
description.et: Kursus annab üldise sissejuhatuse materjalide rollile moodsas tehnoloogias. Põhiosas keskendutakse erinevate materjalidklasside, nende omaduste ja rakenduste tutvustamisele. Harjutatakse vastavasisuliste ülesannete lahendamist.

objectives.en: The goal of the course is to give a systematic picture of the role of materials in modern technology, of the properties and applications of the main classes of materials and of the principles of selection of materials for different application, skills of solving related simple calculational problems.
objectives.et: Kursuse eesmärk on anda süsteemne ettekujutus materjalide rollist moodsas tehnoloogias, olulisemate materjaliklasside omadustest ja rakendustest ning materjalide valiku alustest erinevateks tehnoloogilisteks rakendusteks, oskus lihtsamate teemakohaste arvutusülesannete lahendamiseks.

learning_outcomes.en: The student has the basic understanding of the role of materials in modern technologies, knows the main classes of materials, their properties and application, knows, how to select materials for different applications and is able to perform simple calculations needed.
learning_outcomes.et: Kursuse läbinu mõistab materjalide rolli moodsas tehnoloogias, tunneb põhilisi materjalide klasse ja nende omadusi, oskab põhjendatult valida materjale erinevateks tehnoloogilisteks rakendusteks ning sooritada selleks vajalikke lihtsamaid arvutusi.

description.et:
Hindamine toimub kahe kirjaliku testi summaarse tulemuse alusel.

The grading is based on the summarized results of two written tests.

grade_preconditions.et:
Hindamisele pääsemise eelduseks on kõigi nelja kontrolltesti positiivne sooritus (iga testi summaarne skoor enam kui 50% maksimaalsest võimalikust).
A precondition for the final grading is a positive outcome of all four tests (the score more than 50% of the maximum in each).

grade_evaluation.et:
Lõpliku tulemuse määrab kontrolltestide summarne skoor (% maksimumist): alla 51% - F, 51% kuni 60% - E, 61% kuni 70% - C, 81% kuni 90% - B, 91% kuni 100% - A.
The final grade is determined by the total score (% of the maximum) of all control tests as follows: less than 51% - F, 51% ... 60% - E, 61% ... 70% - C, 81% ... 90% - B, 91% ... 100% - A.

description.et: 1. Introduction. Overview of the course. Materials and society. History of materials. Classification of materials. Materials and technological ability

2. Atomic structure and chemical bonding. Fundamental concepts. Atomic numbers and weights. Isotopes. Hydrogen atom: Bohr's model. Electrons in atoms: atomic orbitals. The periodic table. Interatomic bonds: ionic, covalent and metallic bonds. Hydrogen bond. Van der Waals bonding. Lennard-Jones potential.
3. Principles of crystallography. Symmetry of crystals. Crystal lattice. Unit cell. Crystal systems, Bravais lattices. Ponts, directions and planes in crystals. Anisotropy.
4. Defects in crystals. Impurities. Structural defects. Point defects: vacancies and interstitials. Linear defects: dislocations. Surfaces as defects. Solid solutions. Diffusion in solids.

5. Phase transitions and phase diagrams. Phase transitions of the first and second order. Phase diagrams. Specific points. Gibbs' phase rules. Soft mode and symmetry breaking. Metastable phases. Nucleation.
6. Polycrystalline and amorphous materials. Metals. Ceramics. Microcrystallites. Isotropy. Inorganic and polymer glasses.

7. Elastic properties of materials. Elastic deformation. Hooke's law. Elastic moduli. Young's modulus. Shear modulus. Bulk modulus. Poisson's ratio. Relations. Values. Materials with negative Poisson's ratio.

8. Plastic deformation and fracture of materials. Stress-strain curves. Irreversibility. Yield. Tensile strength. Ductile and brittle materials. Toughness. Fatigue. Micromechanisms of plasticity. Hardness.
9. Heat capacity. Latent heat. Vibrations in solids. Specific heat of crystalline solids: Dulong-Petit. Einstein and Debye models. Phonons. Latent heat. Differential scanning calorimetry.

10. Heat conductivity. Thermal expansion..Heat conductivity in solids. Contribution of electrons. Dependence on structure and temperature. Thermal insulation. Thermal expansion as an anharmonic phenomenon. Uses and dangers.

11. Dielectrics. Mechanisms of dielectric polarization: orientational, ionic and electronic polarizability. Electric permittivity. Dependence on frequency. Electrets. Electrical insulation. Electrical breakdown. Dielectric strength.

12. Electrical conductivity: metals. Energy zones in solids. Electron gas in metals. Mobility of electrons. Conductivity (conductors, semiconductors, insulators). Differential Ohm's law. Values. Dependence on temperatuure. Thermoelectric effects.

13. Semiconductors. Charge carriers: electrons and holes. p- and n-conductivity. p-n junction. Silicon.

14. Ionic conductors. Ionic conductivity in liquids. Solid ionic conductors. Applications in solid fuel cells.
15. Superconductors..Superconductivity. Critical temperature and magnetic field. Meissner effect. Josephson effect. SQUID. High-temperature superconductivity.
Test on lectures 2-15
16. Magnetic properties of materials. Magnetic susceptibility. Diamagnetism. Paramagnetism.

17. Ferromagnetics. Ferromagnetism. Molecular mechanism of ferromagnetic ordering. Magnetic domains. Curie temperature. Hysteresis. Hard and soft ferromagnetics. Magnetic shielding. Magnetic memories.
18. Optical properties of materials: refraction and absorption. Index of refraction. Dispersion (dependence on wavelegth). Gradient-index (GRIN) lens. Negative refraction. Absorption.

19. Optical properties of materials: reflection and scattering. Reflection coefficient. Dependence on the index of refraction. Optical coatings. Total internal reflection. Retroreflective materials. Scattering from bulk and surfaces.

20. Optical properties of materials: polarization. Polaroids. Birefringence. Optical activity. Photoelasticity.
21. Luminescence and luminophores. Types of luminescence: photo- electro-, chemo- and thermo(stimulated)luminescene. Fluorescence and phosphorescence. Luminophores.

22. Lasing and non-linear optical materials. Lasing. Nonlinear optics: second harmonic generation and other nonlinear processes. Optical breakdown. Electro- and magnetooptics. Kerr effect. Faraday effect.
23. Radiation properties of materials. Radiation damage. Radiation resistent materials. Radiation shielding.
24. Structured and metamaterials. Composites. Laminates. Textile. Metamaterials.
25. Surface phenomena. Wetting. Friction. Corrosion. Solid catalysis. Coatings.
26. Sensor and actuator materials. Piezoelectric materials. Electroactive polymers. Shape memory alloys. Electro- and magnetorheological liquids. Ferrofluids.
27. Liquid crystals.Thermotropic liquid crystals. Orientational and positional (1D, 2D) ordering. Nematics. Smectics. Cholesterics. Lyotropic liquid crystals.
28. Materials technologies.Purification. Crystal growth. Casting. Powder metallurgy. Surface coating. Laser technologies. Biotechnologies.
29. Nanomaterials and nanotechnology.Size-properties relations. Optical properties of nanocrystals. Colloids. Molecular manipulation. Molecular machines. Self-assembling.
30. Methods of materials studies. Microscopy. Optical microscopy. Electron microscopy. Scanning probe microscopy. Diffraction-based methods. x-ray scattering. Electron scattering. Neutron scattering.
Test on lectures 16-30
